_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Silver Creek Processing Plant (Silver Creek Plant) utilizes more than the threshold quantity of a regulated flammable substance (10,000 pounds) in the processing of natural gas, where natural gas liquids (NGL) are extracted from the inlet gas using a cryogenic process and treated by an amine unit prior to being delivered to the pipeline for further market distribution. Therefore, this Facility is subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).



The Silver Creek Plant is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and public receptors are located within the worst-case release scenario for the plant. Therefore, the Silver Creek Plant is subject to Program 3 requirements as stated in 40 CFR 68.10. OSHA's PSM standard closely parallels requirements outlined in USEPA's RMP Rule. All elements required by USEPA's 40 CFR 68  Program 3 Prevention Program are also required by OSHA's PSM. 



The Silver Creek Plant has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any off-site death, injury, or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor. 



The Silver Creek Plant employs twelve (12) full-time employees on-site who will ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the Facility. 



EnLink Midstream Operating, LP (EnLink), formerly Crosstex Energy, submitted the most recent RMP 5-year update for the Silver Creek Plant to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) in September 2011.  The current RMP includes administrative updates associated with the change from Crosstex Energy to EnLink.  



ACC

IDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Silver Creek Plant maintains a policy of safe NGL extraction operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the extraction processes, and reducing subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.   



The Silver Creek Plant has procedures in place, including both on-site activities and coordination with off-site responders that are to be followed in the event of a NGL release.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Silver Creek Plant processes NGL in various aboveground vessels and associated piping and valves. NGL is a regulated flammable mixture that is an aliphatic and aromatic hydrocarbon mixture. The regulated flammable chemicals contained in the NGL mixture include methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, N-butane, isopentane, and N-pentane. The maximum volume of NGL at the Facility at any given time is 85,857 gallons (336,755 pounds). The largest NGL tank is 54,068 gallons (212,070 pounds).  Natural gas condensate is also stored at the Facility.  Although the MSDS for this product does not list it as having RMP-regulated components, the composition of natural gas condensate is variable and may at times contain up to 40 percent pentane.  The facility has chosen to consider the natural gas condensate as an RMP-regulated material.  The maximum volume of natural gas condensate at the Facility at any given time is 56,089 gallons (374,463 pounds).  The largest natural gas condensate tank is 53,084 gallons (354,402 pounds).



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Silver Creek Plant maintains a consistent accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases of NGL and natural gas condensate. As previously indicated, the Prevention Program required under 40 CFR 68 is identical to the Prevention Program required under OSHA's PSM. The Silver Creek Plant's

Prevention Program 3 elements, as required under 40 CFR 68 Subpart D, are included in the Facility's PSM Plan, which is kept on-site as a separate document. Required elements include: 



?    Employee Participation,

?    Process Safety Information,

?    Process Hazard Analysis,

?    Operating Procedures,

?    Training,

?    Contractors,

?    Pre-startup Review,

?    Mechanical Integrity,

?    Hot Work Permits,

?    Management of Change,

?    Incident Investigation, and

?    Compliance Audits.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENTAL HISTORY



The Silver Creek Plant has had no accidental releases of NGL or natural gas condensate that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or any environmental impact for the period of five (5) years prior to September 2011.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Silver Creek Plant maintains written Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan (EP&RP) that provides guidance for emergencies expected at the Facility. Further safety information is also detailed in the EP&RP. In addition, operating procedures and equipment design codes and standards associated with the operations at the Facility are maintained. Furthermore, the Facility has coordinated the emergency response plan with the Parker County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Parker County Sheriff's Department. The Parker County Sheriff's Department is designated as the First Responder in the event of NGL release.  For these reasons, the Silver Creek Plant meets the exceptions listed in 40 CFR 68.90(b) and therefore the Facility is not required to have the Emergency Response Program of 40 CFR 68.95. 



A site map, MSDSs, and a list of chemicals kept on-site are maintained at the Facility. Complete details on the Emergency Response Program required under the PSM Rules are included in the Silver Creek Plant's PSM Plan, which is kept on-site as a separate document.  



SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS



The Facil

ity completed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) to assess potential areas to improve safety at the Facility.  Action items from the PHA included adding product detection monitors, adding alarm systems, and other engineering controls.  The final action item from the PHA was completed in April 2011.
